content: I am not able to join
I was just chatting with @Doc Jones in priv msg but might as well bring it here
I'm not really sure what's the best way to go forward, but I am quite sure that >100 attendees is not practical :)
I guess people really want to read rustc source code!
Google met might be a good alternative, up to 250 people
I'm a bit worried that folks think they're getting something they're not
(e.g., a structured presentation)

Well, I see a few options

  • Cancel today and adopt some kind of "invitation" scheme or something to limit total attendance
fwiw, I thought it was going to be "point at area of code, read in mostly silence for awhile", with maybe some people who knew stuff around to answer questions
I would guess that things will slow down after a session or two

Chris said:

fwiw, I thought it was going to be "point at area of code, read in mostly silence for awhile", with maybe some people who knew stuff around to answer questions

this is pretty much the idea :)
well, a bit more structured, but not that much
• Try to move to google meet

nikomatsakis said:

  • Try to move to google meet

I think for the first meeting, it might be good to move to Google Meet to at least talk with people on what this could be?
I guess we can try to tweet out the meet url
let me create it I guess :)
https://meet.google.com/cfm-xasx-cnj?pli=1
Are folks able to join that?
I don't have much experience with google meet

nikomatsakis said:

I don't have much experience with google meet

You'll have to allow us in I think
seems like i have to be explicitly permitted to join
oh, that won't do
Admin has to admit people
I'm also not seeing any sort of prompt
There is a way to allow anyone with a link, without explicit permission.
meet also has 100 members limit
having a discussion with > 100 people on a video call sounds tough lol (and it looks like you're going to have to click the button >100 times to let people in too, which seems like a lot)
Can try Jitsi ?
I know it was supposed to be "not recorded", but maybe something like streaming to twitch or youtube would work in the future
Though if you more people the prompt shows admit all option
Jitsi has a 100 people limit as well

Chris said:

I know it was supposed to be "not recorded", but maybe something like streaming to twitch or youtube would work in the future

I think it was specifically inteded to be an interactive format, which doesn't really play well with Twitch et al?
I can't find a way to make it work :)
I think at this stage I am inclined to cancel for today and try again, but this time have people register their attendance
which should already limit the number of people
But @Doc Jones I'm curious what your take is :)
If you want, I can buy a zoom plan to allow up to 500 people and set up a meeting for today? (Should work)
Honestly I partly just don't want to have >100 people :)
I agree. We can't make it work today. I'm delighted that so many people are interested.
Is anyone present in the Zoom meeting?
https://support.google.com/meet/thread/33894007/allow-external-users-to-join-google-meet-if-they-have-the-link-without-requiring-someone-to-accept?hl=en
It would be nice if there was a way to allow more lurkers to "participate"
i am
Lots of us are :P
I'm here.

Mario Carneiro said:

It would be nice if there was a way to allow more lurkers to "participate"

yes, we can think on that

nikomatsakis said:

Is anyone present in the Zoom meeting?

We're relaying what you say
however
I do think that there is a downside
part of the idea here was for people to feel comfortable asking questions
I'm concerned that if it's too big, that effect won't work
not sure how to combine that with scaling :)
But whats to say > 100 will not want to register ?
Maybe we could have multiple smaller meetings? Like how universities break up big lectures into groups with teaching assistants (TAs) for discussion?
Are there enough people familiar to lead like break outs?
I expect people will register, but we can do a lottery or something like that, or try to multiple meeetings.
I would be surprised if there were enough compiler team/contributors to lead multiple sessions.
And/or we could add in some entry criteria :)
Make the registration link the result of a puzzle or online treasure hunt so people have to put some effort in :)
which would be a bit of a shame but .. maybe it has to be
yeah, most files/areas really only have 2-3 people who know them well :sweat_smile:
Having lots of people ask questions may work in a more "Twitch chat" model though, although it would require a few people to take the lead and be the ones on stream
I'm gratified so many people are interested, I've literally never had this kind of problem before!
I would really prefer if it were as open as possible. Gatekeeping people doesn't sound good imo
We could do a rotation of compiler modules. Each module = 1 leader in one room. And then next time you join a different module's room

there may be a lot of people who are interested but may not continue to attend through the weeks, might be a first week problem, so splitting out into smaller groups for the first few sessions alone might work

Jacob said:

there may be a lot of people who are interested but may not continue to attend through the weeks, might be a first week problem, so splitting out into smaller groups for the first few sessions alone might work

I fully agree with this!
yeah, a lottery or any other way of gatekeeping don't sound good :/
Agreed
maybe you could do something like @matklad is doing with Explaining Rust Analyzer series, but live on twitch?
:+1:üèª

https://twitter.com/nikomatsakis/status/1456295358527647754

Woah! Apparently there are a TON of people interested in the rustc reading club! So many that the zoom room can't accommodate it. @mojosd and I decided to cancel the session for today and retool to think about how to scale up, given this level of interest. Stay tuned! @rustlang

- Niko Matsakis (@nikomatsakis)
Happy to hear the suggestions though, it seems clear there's a desire here, so I think that retooling in some way makes sense.

One idea: Maybe have a small group of 5-10 people who meet and read in advance in return for TAing breakout sessions for a larger audience? This may be too much work for the actual folks familiar with the rustc codebase though :shrug:

Chris Zehner said:

One idea: Maybe have a small group of 5-10 people who meet and read in advance in return for TAing breakout sessions for a larger audience? This may be too much work for the actual folks familiar with the rustc codebase though :shrug:

This sounds like a really great idea :D
my take is
well, I don't know yet, I have to mull it over
I don't think that training TAs seems great, but @Doc Jones and I were always hoping to have more folks leading sessions
I'd still like to start smaller to iterate till we get a good format
I guess we can have a seperate topic completely for discussing only ideas and people can vote upon or something?
